( 34 )
termine all indictments whatsoever taken
before the same Justices, of us, our heirs
and
by the Common Council. A Recorder * to be
chosen, a Barrister of five years standing, to be approved
under the royal hand. That there be twelve
Aldermen, the Recorder the senior Alderman. That
they be resident in the city, and no one elected for
Mayor, Sheriff, or Alderman, that shall voluntarily
absent himself when to be sworn, and a fine, not
exceeding five hundred pounds, be imposed on those
refusing to be chosen, unless they swear that they are
not worth two thousand pounds. The Mayor and
Aldermen to be Justices of the Peace, and to punish
offenders at the Sessions four times a year. That
a Town Clerk † be chosen by them, a Barrister of
three
* In all probability, William de Colford was the
first Recorder of Bristol, as early as the eighteenth
of Edward the Third.
† This office is very ancient here. By an order of
the third and fourth of Philip and Mary, residence
is enjoined him, that he may always assist
the Mayor, &c. with his advice, draw up orders,
&c.
